Keywords: General purpose technology Cost sharing Super-conflict equilibrium Incentive mechanism
A B S T R A C T
The research and development (R&D) of general purpose technologies (GPTs) is a collaborative effort of innovation involving multiple stakeholders, which has received extensive attention worldwide. Considering the characteristics of China's R&D of Nano-GPT, this research mainly makes two contributions: (1) Based on the theory of conflict analysis, a theoretical framework of Chinese GPTs super-conflict equilibrium is constructed to analyze the decision-making behavior among stakeholders, which enriches the theory of GPTs; (2) Under the framework of super-conflict equilibrium of GPTs, an incentive mechanism is designed to promote the R&D of GPTs from the perspective of cost sharing, and its incentive effect is stable and sustainable. In addition, taking “Suzhou Institute of Nano-Tech and Nano-Bionics (SINANO) of Jiangsu in China” as a case, this paper provides some interesting management suggestions through numerical simulation analysis, which are more suitable for developing countries with similar R&D situation in China's GPTs.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Technological innovation and development have greatly increased productivity, especially for general purpose technologies (GPTs) (Abernathy and Townsend, 1975; Aithal and Aithal, 2018; Cardona et al., 2013; Lipsey et al., 2005). Many developed countries such as USA and Japan have formulated GPTs development plans and strategies with great foresight (Shum and Watanabe, 2007). Some GPTs generated by the combination of technologies and business models contribute to the penetration of products across the economy (Larsson, 2018). In addition, relevant research shows that the development of GPTs plays an important role in the internationalization of innovation activities, and is also closely related to the internationalization of innovative enterprises (Qiu and Cantwell, 2018). Stated alternatively, the GPTs have a positive impact from the national level to the enterprise level. Currently, the manufacturing industry in China is situated in the key period of time of transition and structural optimization. It desperately needs to strengthen the research and development (R&D) of general purpose industrial technologies in order for them to play the roles of driving and supporting innovation, especially at key technological links and in emphasized sectors. Such R&D represents an effective path for China of
successfully transiting from China-Made to China-Innovated country. As the largest developing country, China is constantly investing talents, resources and funds in the R&D of GPTs.
China has always attached great importance to the development of GPTs and has continuously invested in its R&D. In 1962, the “1963- 1972 Science and Technology Development Plan” proposed the concept of “technical science” with similar connotations to GPTs. The plan clarifies that “the task of each discipline of technical science is to focus on scientific theories that are common in all sectors of industrial production and engineering technology to solve various industrial production and engineering problems.” In 2006, the State Council issued the “National Medium- and Long-Term Science and Technology Development Plan (2006- 2020)”, which mentioned “common technology” 10 times. Since 2011, China has issued the “Guidelines for the Development of Key Technologies for Industry” to guide and support relevant industries and enterprises to develop key technologies for common application around national strategic needs. Consequently, China has achieved great success in the R &D of nanotechnology. The inspiration for nanotechnology comes from a speech by the late physicist Richard Feynman in 1959 entitled “There is still a lot of space at the bottom”. GPTs in the 21st century, which has been demonstrated in many existing studies (Aithal and Aithal, 2018; Shea et al., 2011; Youtie et al., 2008). Nanotechnology is still in its early stages, but it has produced a series of inventions and patents, and nanotechnology is complementing existing technologies and innovations (Nikulainen and Palmberg, 2010).
Unlike developed countries such as the United States, China's nanotechnology R&D is mainly funded by the state (government) and lacks private capital investment (Appelbaum et al., 2011). This is mainly determined by China's economic structure, that is, the public ownership economy is the mainstay, and multiple ownership economies are developing together. Therefore, China's Nano-GPTs research and development is led and motivated by public institutions such as the government (Shi and Guan, 2016), and its funds penetration is more extensive and deeper. In recent years, the number of Nano-related papers published by China has been ranked first in the world (Zhu et al., 2017). The number of Nano-patents in China has grown rapidly and is emerging as a strong research country in nanotechnology. Among them, the Chinese government has played a key leading role in guiding and supporting the R&D of nanotechnology through various incentives. However, China's nanotechnology R&D also has problems such as lack of private investment (Appelbaum et al., 2011), insufficient commercialization, and a lack of vitality caused by a large amount of public investment. Therefore, in view of the characteristics of China's GPTs R& D, this paper attempts to construct a theoretical framework of superconflict equilibrium and study the incentive mechanism of China's GPTs R&D. In addition, based on the nanotechnology case study, this paper provides management advice and theoretical support for GPTs in China and related developing countries.
The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. In Section 2, we review GPTs-related literature. Based on literature review and characteristics of the R&D of China's Nano-GPTs, a theoretical framework for super-conflict equilibrium is proposed in the context of common technology. In Section 3, under the premise of the concept of superconflict equilibrium, we design an incentive mechanism for R&D of China's Nano-GPTs and discuss related issues. In Section 4, taking Jiangsu Nanotechnology Industry Innovation Center as an example, we describe the numerical experiments that provide beneficial managerial insights. In Section 5, we summarize the findings, identify deficiencies, and highlight future research efforts.

sections.heading: 2.1. Literature review
sections.text:
In the book “The Development of Generic Technologies: The Cognitive Aspects”, Granberg and Stankiewicz (1981) clearly stated that generic techniques are the integration of natural processes, causal links, and techniques that can perform certain functions. As a result, GPTs have entered people's horizons. Since concept of GPTs is first introduced by Advanced Technology Program in 1988 (Huber, 1991), the interpretation of its characteristic has attracted enthusiastic discussions among scholars. The literature in this research field has identified several characteristics of GPTs, such as public product (Tassey, 2012), scientific fact, scientific concepts, technical components, product processes, scientific investigations (Mclaughlin, 1990), technological innovation (Calvano, 2006; David, 1989), much scope for improvement (Lipsey et al., 1998; Rosenberg and Trajtenberg, 2004), widely used (Lipsey et al., 1998), technological complementarities (Lipsey et al., 1998), and growth effects (Bresnahan, 2010; Helpman, 2009; Ristuccia and Solomou, 2014). In general, these characteristics of GPTs can be categorized as follows: (1) Pervasiveness- GPTs should spread to most sectors; (2) Improvement - GPTs should get better over time and, hence, should keep lowering the costs of its users; (3) Innovation spawning - GPTs should make it easier to invent and produce new products or processes (Bresnahan and Trajtenberg, 1995;
Jovanovic and Peter, 2005). Moreover, the three characteristics mentioned above are also important reference standards for identifying GPTs. Based on these three characteristics, most scholars have obtained a series of rich research results in the theory of GPTs recognition. Referring to the calculation of the HHI index, Moser and Nicholas (2004) defined the calculation method of the technical commonality index to determine whether a technology is a GPT. Feldman and Yoon (2011) proved that CohenBoyer's rDNA technology was a GPT, and proposed two qualitative GPTs measurement indicators: technology complementarity and technical applicability. According to the patent data of the US Patent and Trademark Office, Hall and Trajtenberg (2004) identified GPTs by means of technical commonality, number of citations, citation lag, and patent classification growth. Youtie et al. (2008) demonstrated whether nanotechnology could become a common technology from the three characteristics of universality, innovation and wide range of influences. Schultz and Joutz (2010) proposed a method for identifying emerging common technologies by studying the patent citation data of analytical techniques and the patent citation model of technology clusters. Clarke et al. (2015) used firm-level data to assess whether telecommunication services were GPTs. These studies involve various aspects, such as identification methods, identification index systems, and identification cases, and have developed and enriched the technology recognition theory about GPTs to some extent.
GPTs have revolutionarily changed from current technological trajectories (Bresnahan, 2010). GPTs, as path-breaking innovations, are driven by several concomitant forces (Helpman, 1998a, 1998b). Supporting the human development and socio-economic progress in complex societies, GPTs are defined as a technology that produces innovation in many industries and exhibits the characteristics of “cumulative, dynamic and complementary” (Qiu and Cantwell, 2018). However, how to explain the source of common technology and its fundamental driving force is particularly important. Coccia (2015) established a theoretical framework for global leadership-driven innovation to try to explain the general source of GPTs and general path of technological innovation, which is fruitful and provides a basic theoretical framework and a new perspective to study the origins of common technologies. After that, Coccia (2018a) proposed that the changes in the long-wave structure brought about by the war stimulated the development of GPTs. Recently, Coccia (2018b) presented a fishbone diagram for technical analysis, which could identify, explore and analyze whenever possible, the potential root causes of the source and evolution of GPTs. Based on network analysis, Korzinov and Savin (2018) turned the emergence of GPTs into a technical adoption problem, proving that knowledge diffusion, concentration of R&D efforts and variation in the rank of expected returns on products would accelerate the emergence of common technology. By studying the relationship between the search width and technology of different knowledge domains, Ardito et al. (2016) analyzed how the general technology in the field of green energy develops. These studies show us far-sighted insights about the origins and developmental dynamics of common technologies.
GPTs have a strong externality, and its diffusion affects economic development and social change to a certain extent. The main point of early research is “Growth that is driven by general purpose technologies is different from growth driven by incremental innovation. Unlike incremental innovation, GPTs can trigger an uneven growth trajectory, which starts with a prolonged slowdown followed by a fast acceleration”, which has been referred by Helpman (2009), Bresnahan and Trajtenberg (1995), Helpman and Trajtenberg (1994), Helpman (1998a), Aghion and Howitt (2000), Jovanovic and Peter (2005). At early stages, two typical examples of GPTs were electrical technology and steam technology. Goldfarb (2005) analyzed the diffusion of electric motor and found that the longer lag time was determined by the degree of technical difficulty in the application. Ristuccia and Solomou (2014) believed that the productivity brought by GPTs was different in
the economy and industry, and the ability of GPTs to predict growth was limited. Taking the ICT commonality technology as an example, Liao et al. (2016) got the same conclusion as the earlier research, that is, the common technology would increase productivity, while this positive impact had a hysteresis. Rainer and Strohmaier (2014) proposed a multi-sector diffusion model to simulate the diffusion of GPTs in different sectors. With the externality and diffusion of GPTs, Gambardella and McGahan (2010) studied an innovative business model that included upstream and downstream companies - the development of GPTs for licensing to downstream specialists. Studying the diffusion theory of GPTs helps us understand the relationship between GPTs and economic growth and make better use of GPTs to promote productivity.
The process of creating new knowledge/technology is often accompanied by uncertainty and information asymmetry, which makes it difficult to coordinate technology R&D (Arrow, 1972). In China, the R& D of GPTs represents collaborative and complementary innovation activities that involve joint efforts and cooperation of many self-interest driven entities, such as business enterprises, research institutions, universities, consulting firms, financial organizations, and others. However, complementary innovative activities are widely dispersed throughout the economy, making it very difficult to coordinate and provide adequate innovation incentives to the GPT and application sectors (Bresnahan and Trajtenberg, 1995). Therefore, how to design an incentive plan or incentive mechanism to coordinate the R&D and technological innovation of GPTs is one very important problem. The existing literature mainly explains the characteristics of common technologies, identifies common technologies, and analyzes the diffusion effects of common technologies from the macro level and case analysis. Based on the R&D of China's Nano-GPT, this paper aims to explore how to improve the level of GPTs R&D from the perspective of incentive mechanism design, in order to make some contributions to the research of GPTs. Considering the characteristics of China's Nano-GPTs R&D, we first build a theoretical framework of super-conflict equilibrium, and then design a GPTs R&D incentive mechanism based on the super-conflict equilibrium.

sections.heading: 2.2. Theoretical framework of super-conflict equilibrium in the R&D of GPTs
2.2.1. Synergistic relationship of stakeholders
sections.text: The R&D of Nano-GPTs is a high-risk, high-cycle, and high-input multi-agent collaborative process. In China, due to the large proportion of public investment, the R&D of Nano-GPTs has gradually formed a government-led R&D model (Gao and Yan, 2016; Wang et al., 2019; Zhang et al., 2015). This kind of R&D model often exists in the form of a GPT industry research institute, where the government is at the core and a large number of other R&D subjects are subordinate. In technological innovation activities, the dynamic behaviors and interaction mechanisms of stakeholders influence the development and effects of technological innovation, and at the same time produce different influences at different stages, and the ways of influence are also different (Ya and Rui, 2006). The R&D of GPTs represents collaborative activities that involve joint efforts and cooperation of many self-interest driven entities, such as business enterprises, research institutions, universities, consulting firms, financial organizations, and others. Therefore, in the government-led GPTs value chain, each R&D stakeholder is related to each other through transactional relationships, and constitutes a GPTs cooperation development and production synergy network with the government. The synergistic network has many stakeholders, and has core (the government) and subordinate subjects, as shown in Fig. 1.

sections.heading: 2.2.2. Collaborative interest subject hyper-conflict modeling in GPTs R&D
sections.text:
Definition 1. Super conflict. As the core role of the government-led GPTs R&D system, the government has certain control rights to each R& D stakeholder, and can adjust the activities of each node. At the same
time, the government takes advantages of rights, information and other conditions to maximize the overall benefits of the R&D system, so that even if there is unilateral improvement, the subordinate subject will not choose to improve, deviate from the Nash equilibrium, thus creating super-conflict among various stakeholders.
The super-conflict analysis method is a theory that quickly models and analyzes conflicts in real life. In China's R&D system of GPTs, the super-conflicts analysis among the R&D subjects is essential to bridge the contradictions and conflicts between the government and various stakeholders. In the process of realizing the transfer and flow of interests from one subject to another, we need to find a balance of satisfaction between the parties, so that possible conflicts of interest can be minimized or to an acceptable level. The super-conflict equilibrium mainly includes components of players, action strategies, states, interests, and perceptual mapping games.
Definition 2. Super conflict model of Nano-GPTs R&D.
(1) Player. In the R&D system of GPTs, there are two types of people in the game, the super players and the general players. The government is a super player, who has higher rights and status than the general players and information superiority. The government can control the situation and resources of the system, and exert force on the general players to influence their decision-making behaviors. The government's force on general players is expressed in χi, where i(i=1,2,⋯,n) is general player. Each R&D subject is a general player, with a status, decision-making, and information set that is lower than the super player of government.
(2) Action strategy and State. In the GPTs R&D system, each R&D stakeholder selects a combination (action strategy) of effort level sil and cooperation level cil. As a result, these strategies constitute a common technology R&D state ul, representing a conflict situation, expressed as ul(l=1,2,⋯,p). The set of all feasible states forms a GPT R&D state space, expressed as U= u1× u2×⋯× ul×⋯× up, where p is the total number of feasible states, ∀l∈ [1,p]. It should be noted that the level of effort and cooperation is very important in technology R&D innovation. The level of effort is usually measured by spending on R&D, number of employees working in R&D, number of hours given over to R &D, spending on R&D/volume of sales, and spending on R&D/number of employees (Nieto and Quevedo, 2005). In addition, as a complement to the level of effort, the level of cooperation also affects the efficiency of technology development and innovation (Belderbos et al., 2004; De Marchi, 2012; Katz, 1986).

sections.heading: 2.2.3. Stability analysis of super conflict equilibrium
sections.text:
In China's R&D system of Nano-GPTs, The first is that the general players use their own methods (in general, aiming at maximizing their profits) to understand the R&D conflict issues of GPTs, determine their own efforts and cooperation. At this point, Nash equilibrium is reached. Secondly, on the basis of the general conflict equilibrium, the super player continues to improve unilaterally, which leads to an increase in overall interest. The general players improve their efforts and cooperation through perceptual mapping. Although the gains may be relatively poor, in view of long-term cooperation and cooperative income compensation, the general players would still accept the strategy. Therefore, the R&D system of GPTs realizes the movement from general equilibrium to super-conflict equilibrium, and obtains a super-equilibrium between Nash equilibrium and Shapley value equilibrium, as shown in Fig. 2. Nash equilibrium is based on the interests of the general players and does not consider the interests of the GPTs R&D system. Shapley equilibrium reflects the willingness, value and status of cooperation among the general players to a certain extent. While the interests or claims of some R&D subjects cannot be satisfied or their losses are large (the benefits are less than those when they are not cooperative), the R&D system of GPT cannot achieve Pareto efficiency optimally, which makes the equilibrium state not stable.

sections.heading: 3. Study design
sections.text:
As we all know, the R&D investment of GPTs is very large, which leads to higher R&D costs. In China, the R&D of Nano-GPT is a complex system engineering that requires high R&D costs. It represents a series of coordinated activities of such organizations or innovation alliances, including institutions of higher learning, business enterprises, research institutes, financial organizations, etc. However, such coordinated activities themselves cannot make direct profits from the marketplace, but make profits from consequent and ultimate practical applications. Therefore, the indirect profits will be referred as expected return or profits in the rest of this paper.
The essence of the R&D process is to create value by the organizational system of the R&D of GPTs; and the profits of the R&D organizational system are affected by the levels of efforts and degrees of collaboration of the stakeholders, which additionally plays a role in the distribution of the expected profits. For this reason, the levels of efforts and the degrees of collaboration of the stakeholders are regarded as important parameters of the cooperative R&D of GPTs (Fu and Piplani, 2004). In R&D activities of GPTs, due to such development characteristics of high inputs, high risk, etc., the government can, to a certain degree, help coordinate the behaviors and the profit relationship of the stakeholders by mobilizing its resources, such as funds, law enforcement, introduction of policies, etc. To produce additional expected profit and to realize sustainable and healthy development of their business, the stakeholders tend to actively cooperate with the government by developing GPTs jointly. So, to a certain degree, the government and the stakeholders follow the setup of a master-slave game with the former in the master position and the latter in the slave position. Considering the significance and effect of GPTs on the entire society and the prohibitively huge capital investment, the government often
employs the method of sharing R&D costs with the stakeholders in order to incentivize them by coordinating their joint effort so that the stakeholders will be willing to invest in their individual efforts and collaboration in terms of labor, capital, equipment, knowledge, etc. With investments in effort and collaboration, the stakeholders also capture certain amounts of profits, which in turn affect the expected returns of the R&D system as a whole and the stakeholders individually. In view of this, we design incentive mechanism from the perspective of government cost sharing based on theoretical framework of superconflict equilibrium proposed in Section 2, and analyze the game behavior of GPT R&D stakeholders.

sections.heading: 3.1. Basic assumptions
sections.text:
Assumption 1. Assume that there is a R&D organization or innovation alliance established for developing GPTs that consists of n stakeholders as business enterprises, institutions of higher learning, research centers, technology intermediaries, financial organizations, consulting firms, etc. This organization or alliance is referred as a R&D system of GPTs (nanotechnology). Such a system also stands for a synergistic relationship, denoted as N={1,⋯, i,⋯,n}, where i represents a R&D stakeholder, a rational person or a business entity. Within this collaborative R&D network system, the government is situated in a dominating position and can coordinate the R&D behaviors and interests of the n stakeholders because of its advantages in terms of such resources as funds, law enforcements, introduction of policies, etc.. The stakeholders act as subordinates and actively participate in the R&D of GPTs under the influence of the government.
Assumption 2. The realization of the overall profit of the R&D organization or alliance of GPTs is a result of the invested efforts and collaboration of the stakeholders. Moreover, the level of a stakeholder's effort affects not only its own expected profit, but also that of the entire R&D organization. Generally speaking, the level of an individual stakeholder's effort is mainly expressed by its inputs of various resources, such as labor, capital, equipment, knowledge, etc. Only with sufficient investment in effort and collaboration from all the stakeholders, it can guarantee the R&D success of GPTs so that added values can be created by the R&D system. Therefore, the levels of effort and the degrees of collaboration of the individual stakeholders represent the key factors that affect the profits of the R&D system. Assume that si, ci denote the level of effort and the degree of collaboration of stakeholder i respectively, satisfying 0 < ci≤1 and si > 0.
Assumption 3. The government only shares the cost of efforts of the R& D stakeholders of GPTs without providing any help for the R&D costs of the entire R&D system.

sections.heading: 3.3. An incentive mechanism for sharing the R&D costs of GPTs
sections.text:
In the R&D system of GPTs, each stakeholder can choose either collaboration or no collaboration R&D strategies. In the short term, some R&D stakeholders choose non-cooperative R&D strategies, while others choose cooperative R&D strategies. These two R&D strategies may exist at the same time. In the long run, because the non-cooperation of other stakeholders leads to the failure of the interests of the R&D system of GPT, the interests of the stakeholders who choose the cooperative R&D strategy are not guaranteed. As a punishment for other stakeholders, they will also choose non-cooperative R&D strategies. And no matter whether a stakeholder decides to collaborate or not, it makes the decision on its optimal level of effort by maximizing either its self-interest or the profit of the R&D system.
If stakeholder i chooses the strategy of not collaborating with others, he solves for his optimal level of effort by maximizing his individual profit. Based on the analysis of the optimal decision making of the individual stakeholders and the R&D system under the assumption of collaboration and that of no collaboration, too much investment in effort and collaboration can potentially lower a stakeholder's expected profit. Therefore, some stakeholders may not want to collaborate with other stakeholders to achieve maximizing individual profits, which will most likely make the profit of the R&D system not maximized. That, of course, will in turn affect adversely the overall expected profit and coordination of the system. Considering the significance and impacts of the GPTs on the common wealth of the society and the prohibitively huge amounts of capital needed, the government often helps cover part of the R&D cost of the stakeholders to motivate the enthusiasms and initiatives of the stakeholders and to resolve the conflict between the R &D system and individual stakeholders. Such government support encourages stakeholders to form collaborative R&D relationships so that they will consequently invest in manpower, capital, equipment, knowledge, etc., with their corresponding levels of effort and degrees of collaboration. However, due to the limitations in the government's ability and funds, only a portion of the R&D costs of the stakeholders can be subsidized. That is, the government can only help coordinate the stakeholders up to a certain extent, beyond which the stakeholders need to invest in additional levels of effort and degrees of collaboration to materialize coordinated innovations according to the optimization of the R&D system. At this junction, for individual stakeholders, their expected profits should not be lowered because of the government's sharing of the R&D costs; and the government's sharing of the cost when the strategy of no collaboration is adopted is used as the starting point of negotiation. For the R&D system, its expected profit with government's incentives should be higher than that before receiving any government support under the condition of no collaboration, while the invested effort levels of the stakeholders are not lower than those when there is no collaboration among them.

Beijing, Shanghai, Jiangsu, and Anhui stand out for having the leading centers of nanotechnology and well-known nanotech scientists (Appelbaum et al., 2011). Beijing and Shanghai are seen as leading areas for nanotechnology R&D; however the greater Shanghai region, including Jiangsu and Zhejiang, experienced faster growth than the traditionally productive Beijing region (Motoyama et al., 2014). Therefore, taking “Suzhou Institute of Nano-Tech and Nano-Bionics (SINANO), Jiangsu, China” as an example, considering the particularity and confidentiality of Nano-GPTs R&D, we carry out numerical simulation of the theoretical framework and incentive mechanism proposed in this paper. The Suzhou Institute of Nano-Tech and Nano-Bionics of the Chinese Academy of Sciences (referred to as the Suzhou Institute of Nano-sciences of the Chinese Academy of Sciences) was jointly funded by the Chinese Academy of Sciences and the People's Government of Jiangsu Province, the Suzhou Municipal People's Government and the Suzhou Industrial Park. The research institute will closely integrate knowledge innovation, technological innovation and regional innovation in the process of creation and development, and face the needs of regional economic and social development, and cooperate with the units of the national innovation system to promote the transfer of scientific and technological achievements and integrate into the economic and social innovation value chain. And for the R&D system of GPTs, the overall expected profit is optimized and is close to the system's optimal expected profit in the case of collaboration. These observations indicate that under the conditions that the overall expected profit of the R&D system of GPTs is optimized and each stakeholder's expected profit is at least maintained, the equilibrium strategies will get evolved based on the concept of equilibria of super conflicts and materialize the Pareto optimization, while mobilizing the stakeholders' enthusiasms and initiatives to invest additionally in their levels of efforts.

From the perspective of cost sharing, the super-conflict equilibrium incentive mechanism can describe the phenomenon of the R&D of GPTs led by the Chinese government in detail. Under the framework of superconflict equilibrium, the government is the super player, and the R&D subjects are general players. Cost sharing, as a government's force, affects both the costs and benefits of stakeholder. Stakeholders adjust their efforts through Perceptual mapping game, which changes the R&D status of the GPTs R&D system. The multi-agent in the R&D system realizes the collaborative R&D. At this time, the R&D strategy (the level of effort) is exactly the super-conflict equilibrium strategy, which satisfies the Pareto optimality and is more stable and sustainable.

sections.heading: 5. Concluding observations
sections.text:
As the largest developing country, China is in a critical period of economic transformation, and its R&D of GPTs presents a significant government-led character. The government-led R&D of GPTs represented by China is different from the US R&D model. Through the analysis of China's technological R&D of Nano-GPTs, we found that the government is a super player while the R&D subjects are general players. Moreover, the two types of players together constitute a GPTs R &D network. In order to describe China's government-led GPTs R&D phenomenon, we first build a super-conflict equilibrium theory of Chinese R&D of GPTs based on reviewing literature research. Secondly, based on the framework of super-conflict equilibrium theory, we design a GPTs R&D incentive mechanism from the perspective of cost sharing to simulate and analyze the status quo of China's GPTs R&D. Finally, we use SINANO in Jiangsu Province of China as a case to carry out numerical simulation, which verifies the rationality of the model. In addition, some main results and interesting managerial insights are discussed as follows based on the analysis of the models.
(1) In the government-led GPTs R&D system, the government's power is too concentrated, which causes that the enthusiasm of the research and development subject is not high enough and lacks the vitality of technological innovation. In numerical simulation, we find that the government needs to exert a large force on the stakeholders (sharing a lot of R&D costs of stakeholders) in order to improve their efforts and achieve a stable R&D state. Therefore, the government needs to consider decentralizing power to stakeholders (Guo et al., 2018) and enhance the transparency of R&D information, leaving only the necessary powers. China has made good achievements in the basic R&D of Nano-GPT, but its commercialization is not enough, and the market lacks vitality. This is partly due to the government's high centralization. In this regard, the government can let the market allocate technical resources, adhere to market-oriented R&D of GPTs to promote the practical application of technology and commercial output. In other
words, the GPT should be linked to technology demand, FDI (Foreign Direct Investment), and the development of high-tech industries in the country (Huang and Wu, 2012).
(2) In the government-led GPTs R&D system, the cost sharing of the government should be appropriate, rather than as much as possible. Fig. 3, Fig. 7, and Fig. 8 show that the government's special funds are not all used for cost sharing. When the cost sharing reaches a certain level, the level of effort of the stakeholders and the related expected profits will not continue to increase. Therefore, the government can consider appropriate reduction of direct cost sharing and use excessive special funds for indirect subsidies to stakeholders, such as tax exemption (Zhang et al., 2014), interest rate subsidies (Zhang et al., 2014), etc. Fig. 5 and Fig. 6 show that reasonable rewards and punishments can be used as a supplement to the incentive of R&D of GPTs. So, the government can use cash rewards and punishments as an auxiliary or indirect means to compensate for the shortcomings of direct cost sharing. In addition, public R&D investment is therefore a necessary but not sufficient condition for enabling developing countries to promote emerging technologies (Huang and Wu, 2012), the government's direct cost sharing as a public investment squeezes private investment. Therefore, those better-based GPTs government should reduce cost sharing rationally to encourage the involvement of private investment and enhance the vitality of the R&D system.
(3) The R&D of GPTs is also the process of knowledge sharing and delivery. Related research shows that property rights protection is positively and significantly related to R&D activity (Lin et al., 2010), the government should introduce relevant laws and regulations to strengthen the protection of the intellectual property rights of GPTs. It is well known that the R&D of GPTs is a high-risk uncertainty process. The presence of a large degree of uncertainty leads to high R&D risks, resulting in many R&D failures (Wang et al., 2010). In view of this, the government needs to improve risk prediction, risk warning and risk planning to improve the ability of the R&D system to respond to risks. Finally, it is also necessary to build a reasonable personnel training system for GPTs, set up a scientific and technological talent reward system and interest distribution system, and improve the technology intermediary service platform and service system. The above work is to provide good environment and supporting infrastructure for GPTs R&D. Only in this way can the R&D system better realize the R&D state of super-conflict equilibrium and encourage all stakeholders to achieve long-term and stable cooperative R&D.
There are several limitations, which need further study for the future research. The theoretical framework of common technology superconflict equilibrium constructed in this paper is based on Chinese common technology, and its generality needs further verification. In addition, there are many design perspectives for R&D incentives, such as direct funding subsidies, profit distribution, cost sharing, and knowledge sharing. This paper only deals with the perspective of cost sharing, and the design of multi-perspective incentive mechanism based on super-conflict equilibrium is our future work.

metadata.abstractText: The research and development (R&D) of general purpose technologies (GPTs) is a collaborative effort of innovation involving multiple stakeholders, which has received extensive attention worldwide. Considering the characteristics of China's R&D of Nano-GPT, this research mainly makes two contributions: (1) Based on the theory of conflict analysis, a theoretical framework of Chinese GPTs super-conflict equilibrium is constructed to analyze the decision-making behavior among stakeholders, which enriches the theory of GPTs; (2) Under the framework of super-conflict equilibrium of GPTs, an incentive mechanism is designed to promote the R&D of GPTs from the perspective of cost sharing, and its incentive effect is stable and sustainable. In addition, taking “Suzhou Institute of Nano-Tech and Nano-Bionics (SINANO) of Jiangsu in China” as a case, this paper provides some interesting management suggestions through numerical simulation analysis, which are more suitable for developing countries with similar R&D situation in China's GPTs.
